On Monday 18 May 2009, Bill Burke wrote:
> Michael Schuerig wrote:
> > [snip]I think HATEOAS precludes hard-coding application
> > specific intelligence on the client.
>
> I think this "feature" of HATEOAS is misleading.  If you're writing
> an AJAX application, you're still getting "application specific
> intelligence" from the server downloaded as Javascript.  Unless
> you're writing a pure HTML based application, which it seems your
> not, you're gonna break this mythical constraint.  As I keep saying
> over and over, machine-based clients usually have to have application
> specific intelligence to actually work.  Unless you're one of the <
> 1% applications that are generic enough to interpret things on the
> fly.

My statement was too strong. I'll restate it as The client should not 
second-guess the server. Both are conversant in the domain of discourse, 
but the server is the one who sets the rules.

Please, everyone, just forget about the implementation technology I'm 
incidentally using for the client.

Michael
